unnormalised: Managing time in today's fast-paced work environment can feel like a never-ending battle. Especially in India, where we juggle family commitments, social obligations, and of course, our careers. I remember when I first started working at TCS. It was a total shock to my system. Suddenly, my carefully planned days were replaced with a chaotic mix of meetings, deadlines, and urgent requests. I had to quickly learn to manage my time effectively, or I was going to drown.
normalised: Managing time in today's fast-paced work environment can feel like a never-ending battle. Especially in India, where we juggle family commitments, social obligations, and of course, our careers. I remember when I first started working at T-C-S. It was a total shock to my system. Suddenly, my carefully planned days were replaced with a chaotic mix of meetings, deadlines, and urgent requests. I had to quickly learn to manage my time effectively, or I was going to drown.

unnormalised: One of my biggest challenges was scheduling meetings. I’d often find myself in situations where I’d have 3 meetings all scheduled within the same 2-hour window. For example, one memorable Tuesday, I had a client call scheduled for 11:00 AM, followed by a team meeting at 11:30 AM, and then another urgent call with my manager slotted for 12:00 PM. It was impossible to attend all three effectively. I learned the hard way that I needed to prepone or postpone meetings as needed, and to block out travel time, even for just going from one floor to another!
normalised: One of my biggest challenges was scheduling meetings. I’d often find myself in situations where I’d have three meetings all scheduled within the same two-hour window. For example, one memorable Tuesday, I had a client call scheduled for eleven A-M, followed by a team meeting at eleven thirty A-M, and then another urgent call with my manager slotted for twelve P-M. It was impossible to attend all three effectively. I learned the hard way that I needed to prepone or postpone meetings as needed, and to block out travel time, even for just going from one floor to another!

unnormalised: Then there were the Indian Standard Time (IST) nuances. Trying to coordinate with international teams proved to be its own unique brand of chaos. We’d have conference calls scheduled for 8:00 PM IST, which meant I was stuck in the office until late, missing dinner with my family. Or sometimes, the confusion would be worse. Like when a team member thought the meeting was scheduled for 9:30 GMT, not realising it needed to be converted to IST – leading to a missed crucial project discussion. I once even mixed up a project timeline and scheduled my Diwali vacation right when the project was due, 11/11/2024. That did not go down well with my boss!
normalised: Then there were the Indian Standard Time (I-S-T) nuances. Trying to coordinate with international teams proved to be its own unique brand of chaos. We’d have conference calls scheduled for eight P-M I-S-T, which meant I was stuck in the office until late, missing dinner with my family. Or sometimes, the confusion would be worse. Like when a team member thought the meeting was scheduled for nine thirty G-M-T, not realising it needed to be converted to I-S-T – leading to a missed crucial project discussion. I once even mixed up a project timeline and scheduled my Diwali vacation right when the project was due, eleventh november two thousand and twenty four. That did not go down well with my boss!

unnormalised: Another hurdle was balancing work with personal commitments. In India, festivals like Diwali, Holi and Eid are incredibly important. Taking time off during those periods is non-negotiable for many families. I quickly learned to plan my work around these events, ensuring that critical deadlines didn't clash with the festive season. I had to start requesting vacation time well in advance, like 6 months ahead of Durga Puja.

I had to start requesting vacation time well in advance, like six months ahead of Durga Puja.

unnormalised: What truly helped me was using a digital calendar religiously. I'd block out specific time slots for different tasks, including lunch breaks and even short chai breaks. I'd also set reminders well in advance for important deadlines and meetings. I rely on it now so much that I even set reminders for family events.

unnormalised: Eventually, I found a system that worked for me. I still occasionally struggle to balance everything, but now I'm much better equipped to navigate the challenges of time management in the Indian work environment. I hope this helps other freshers out there too!
